Column-average Dry Mole Fractions (DMF) reported in this file were
acquired using a Fourier Transform Spectrometer (FTS) located at the
Wisconsin Tall Tower site (45.945 deg N
sea level).  Direct solar spectra were acquired in the near-infrared
spectral region.  These spectra were used to retrieve column abundances
and calibration procedure are given in
dioxide column abundances at the Wisconsin Tall Tower site

column2: the calibration procedure has evolved. An airmass-correction

column1: is performed for XCO2 which accounts for the fact that due to spectroscopic

column2: XCO2 at all sites is SZA-dependent. This procedure is described in

column1: Dry column-average CO2 DMF has been calculated according to
CO2 DMF = 0.2095 x column CO2 / column O2.
Column CO2 is retrieved for two CO2 bands centered at 6228 cm-1 and
6348 cm-1.  Column O2 is retrieved from the electronic band centered at
7882 cm-1.  The average of the two calculated CO2 DMFs is presented here.
The dry column-average CO2 DMF (0.2095 x column CO2 / column O2) is
affected by three main sources of error:
The standard deviation of column CO2 / column O2 during a one hour period
is better than 0.1% under clear sky conditions and ~0.2% under partly
cloudy conditions.  Repeatability of the measurement is not a significant
The retrieved O2 columns were NOT reduced by 2.27% to bring them into
agreement with the dry surface pressure
al. (2006).  The absolute accuracy of the CO2 retrievals was calibrated
by comparison to integrated aircraft profiles
of 0.99.  The standard deviation of the fitting residuals is ~0.1%.
The aircraft profiles were performed with the sun

column1: now well-calibrated for these values.  However
errors may be present at higher airmass due to errors in the spectroscopy

here. We believe that this error affects both the CO2 and O2 retrievals
